title: E field of distribution - 4 square configurations

content.question: Several straight, uniformly charged segments of wire are arranged in four different configurations that each form a partial square, as shown in the figure. Each segment has the same length <math alttext="s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>s</mi></math> and a charge of either <math alttext="positive Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>+</mo><mi>Q</mi></mpadded></math> or <math alttext="negative Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>-</mo><mi>Q</mi></mpadded></math>, as indicated. Which of the following correctly ranks the electric field magnitudes <math alttext="E sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, <math alttext="E sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, <math alttext="E sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math>, and <math alttext="E sub 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>4</mn></msub></math> at the centers of the squares in the four configurations?

choices.label: <math alttext="E sub 2 is greater than E sub 1, which equals E sub 4, which is greater than E sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>4</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="E sub 2 equals E sub 3, which is greater than E sub 1, which equals E sub 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>4</mn></msub></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="E sub 4 is greater than E sub 2, which equals E sub 3, which is greater than E sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>4</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="E sub 4 is greater than E sub 2, which is greater than E sub 3, which is greater than E sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>4</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="E sub 2 equals E sub 3, which is greater than E sub 1, which equals E sub 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mn>4</mn></msub></mstyle></math>

unit.text: 8: Electric Charges, Fields, and Gauss's Law

skill.text: 2.C: Compare physical quantities between two or more scenarios or at different times and locations in a single scenario.
